content.intro:
At the foot of Lake Michigan, Chicago, nicknamed the Windy City, is built on jazz and sky-scraping bravado.

In a downtown bar an old blues singer with a husky voice sings “Sweet Home Chicago.” Released in 1936, the Robert Johnson standard, since covered by the biggest names in music, is a tribute to this timeless and friendly city. Birthplace of the "Chicago Blues" and a world capital of jazz, the city is full of legendary clubs such as the Green Mill, where Al Capone hung out, which draws as many tourists as the city's many historical monuments, and where the presence of Louis Armstrong, who played here early on in his career, still permeates the atmosphere. Besides its strong musical identity, Chicago shines worldwide for its majestic architecture. In The Loop, the business district and cultural centre, red brick skyscrapers jostle for attention alongside 20th and 21st century masterpieces by Frank Lloyd Wright, Frank Gehry and Renzo Piano. These and other architectural treasures are best viewed by taking the ‘L' rapid transit system, a Chicago landmark. Equally magnificent, and very popular among tourists, is the famous boat cruise along the Chicago River, which offers spectacular panoramas of the city. A true cultural getaway with 40 museums, including the world renowned Art Institute of Chicago, the sweet life that reigns in this, the third largest city in the United States, can also be enjoyed strolling through one of its incredible parks, such as Millennium Park, a veritable open-air art gallery. The warm water of Lake Michigan is a big summertime draw, and a string of sandy beaches stretching as far as the eye can see – 33 in the city centre alone – attracts huge crowds.

map.mapTitle: Our selection of must-see places in and around Chicago

seoData.seoTitle: Travel Guide Chicago  - Plan your trip to Chicago with Air France Travel Guide
seoData.seoDescription: Stay in Chicago: what to visit to Chicago, where to stay, which restaurant to go? All information to prepare your holidays to Chicago with Air France.

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Chicago

content.title: The Godfrey, avant-garde design and surreal view

introduction.small: Cornerstone of Chicago's posh and arty River North district, The Godfrey shines as one of the trendiest hotels in town.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Godfrey, avant-garde design and surreal view

paragraphs.text:
The cubist-inspired architecture stands out in Chicago's landscape. With a neo-industrial style, The Godfrey establishes itself as a resolutely avant-garde hotel. The slate-grey and cocoa-toned rooms are spread over 16 floors. Design is on the stylish side, with velvet sofas and contemporary lampshades.
The establishment is at the cutting edge of technology: everything is accessible at your fingertips in the dedicated application you can download on your phone. When booking your room, ask for one with a breathtaking view over the urban surroundings, especially from the last floor. That vista is famous all around town, as the sophisticated youth regularly gathers on the large wooden tar of the IO Rooftop lounge bar. The latter turns into a club when night falls. An all-around excellent way to delve into modern and trendy Chicago.

The Godfrey
127 W Huron St
Chicago, IL 60654

+1 312 649 2000

www.godfreyhotelchicago.com

Rooms: from 91 USD

content.title: Passerotto, Tuscan take on Korean gastronomy

introduction.small: In Chicago's Andersonville neighbourhood, Passerotto reveals a Korean cuisine revisited with flavours from Italian gastronomy.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Passerotto, Tuscan take on Korean gastronomy

paragraphs.text:
In Italian, Passerotto means “little sparrow”. Looking to name her restaurant, American-Korean chef Jennifer Kim translated the nickname her father used to give her as a child. This is therefore a deeply personal and introspective approach she is taking, paying tribute to Korean gastronomical culture in a series of traditional dishes. Italian touches, Tuscan to be precise, can be traced in dishes that hark back to the chef's memories as a trainee, when she would switch between Korean and Italian restaurants. In a small room that serves 40 people in an industrial setting complete with exposed brick walls, a huge counter takes centre stage with patrons sitting on each side. Delicate, refined and flowery dishes parade in a sublimation of raw and unprocessed ingredients. Indulge in some yellowfin tuna served with corn, hijiki (brown seaweed that looks like a spaghetti) and Thai hot peppers. Unless you go for the Scottish salmon with prunes, or the bay scallops and onion purée in soy sauce. An unusual gourmet fusion that takes the best of both worlds.

Passerotto
5420 N Clark St
Chicago, IL 60640

+1 708 607 2102

www.passerottochicago.com

Menu: around 28 USD

content.title: Old school beer at Fischman Public House

introduction.small: In an almost century-old Chicago building, discover Fischman Public House, a branch of the liquor manufacturer of the same name. A beer bar that mixes tradition and modernity.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Old school beer at Fischman Public House

paragraphs.text:
From the outside, the structure of the place makes Fischman Public House a perfect example of Chicago's old school bars, with large picture windows – reminiscent of Edward Hopper's Nighthawks – exposed red brick facade and walls as well as red and black furniture… In the back of the room behind the counter, your eyes will immediately be drawn by the colourful street art fresco that showcases an angry unicorn and Poseidon's head amidst rough waters.
More than 80 years old, Fischman is first and foremost a distillery. In its new hybrid location blending tavern and specialised shop, Fischman Public House's goal is to unite old and new. The beer bar section now welcomes patrons for local tastings – to be enjoyed in moderation. The pineapple and mango-flavoured Wah Wah or the Indiana old fashioned Lazer Snake will best be paired with a selection of snacks to die for.

Fischman Public House
4058 N Milwaukee Ave
Chicago, IL 60641

+1 773 867 6300

www.fischmanliquors.com ﻿

Menu: beer from 6 USD

content.title: Make your escape to the J. Parker

introduction.small: Delicious and amazing cocktails and breath-taking views—The J. Parker promises you an unforgettable evening.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Make your escape to the J. Parker

paragraphs.text:
If you ask which is the best rooftop in Chicago, the answer will be: The J. Parker. And since the view is worth the trip, you will have to travel up to the very last floor of the Lincoln Hotel. From here, Lincoln Park stretches out under your feet, with its wooded alleys and waterways, beyond which, all of Lake Michigan stretches out to the horizon.

The J. Parker offers a few dishes, but the cocktails are the stars. Each signature cocktail is inspired by a country or region: Thailand, Mexico, Spain, India, Argentina and California. The Italian cocktail, ‘Emerald Mountain', is a must, with its mixture of whiskey, pistachio, apricot and lemon, it offers some unexpected flavours.

Sit on the chairs or the sofas, which are close to the bay windows. You can spend the evening remaking the world, cocktail in hand, in front of this breath-taking view.

The J. Parker
1816 North Clark Street
13th Floor
Chicago, IL 60614

+1 312 254 4747

www.jparkerchicago.com

Cocktail: 13 USD

content.title: The Museum of Contemporary Art—art at its purest

introduction.small: All forms of contemporary art are on view at MCA.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Museum of Contemporary Art—art at its purest

paragraphs.text:
Founded in 1967, the Museum of Contemporary Art (MCA) was initially a gallery that featured temporary exhibitions. Today, it has a superb permanent collection with works by international artists such as Bacon, Mapplethorpe and Kline. In addition to paintings, the museum houses art in all its forms, including music, theatre and dance performances on its stage.

Halfway between Michigan Avenue and Lake Michigan, the museum is a cultural break that is definitely worth a visit. Designed by the German architect Josef Paul Kleihues, it fits perfectly in its environment. Its aluminium facade and large windows make it a very contemporary building, while remaining faithful to the typical architecture of Chicago. Inside, the works are bathed in natural light and the grand staircases of the MCA have become well known thanks to their atypical form.

Museum of Contemporary Art
220 East Chicago Avenue
Chicago, IL 60611

+1 312 280 2660

www.mcachicago.org

content.title: Acme Hotel Company, modern and connected

introduction.small: A few blocks from Mag Mile, this one-of-a-kind boutique hotel has become, since opening in 2013, a favourite destination for connected travellers and design lovers.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Acme Hotel Company, modern and connected

paragraphs.text:
The rooms are beautifully furnished in designer Scandinavian, but it is the little touches that make the difference here, like ‘Morning Joe', one of the hotel's signature pleasures: a thermos of coffee left outside the door at the precise time requested by the guest.

Technogeeks will be smitten by the new free ‘wifi-away' service, through which they can stay connected even when out exploring Mag Mile.

Acme Hotel Company
15 E. Ohio Street
Chicago, IL 60611

+1 312 894 0800

www.acmehotelcompany.com

Rooms: from 161 USD

content.title: Public Hotel, a luxury experience at reasonable prices

introduction.small: The Public Hotel by Ian Schrager, inventor of the boutique hotel concept, has become a benchmark that continues to inspire a new generation of hoteliers.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Public Hotel, a luxury experience at reasonable prices

paragraphs.text:
In this 4-star hotel, enjoying full-on luxury comfort doesn't mean having to break the bank. In a style more inspired by Andrée Putman than Philippe Starck, the renowned designer Ian Schrager, famous for his legendary Club 54 in New York, has left nothing to chance.

An oversized Christian Liaigre table with five computer stations adorns the lobby, and giant bouquets of freshly cut flowers fill every room. In winter, fireplaces are lit in the rooms before each arrival. The Library is an especially convivial spot – café during the day, cocktail bar at night. The Pump Room, featuring the inventive and modern cuisine of Chef Jean-Georges Vongerichten, is as bright as the galaxy of luminous globes illuminating its dining room.

Public Hotel
1301 North State Parkway
Chicago, IL 60610

+1 312 787 3700

www.publichotels.com

Rooms: from 100 USD

content.title: Hotel Chicago Downtown, casual chic in the heart of the city

introduction.small: A first-rate choice on the Chicago River, behind the mythical towers of Marina City, and opposite the equally famous House of Blues.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel Chicago Downtown, casual chic in the heart of the city

paragraphs.text:
Situated in the trendy River North area just a few blocks from Magnificent Mile's concentration shops, bars and restaurants, Hotel Downtown Chicago offers many benefits: the service is as discreet as it is efficient, the rooms are stylish and refined, the extra-wide beds are exceptionally comfortable, and the architectural wonders of Chicago are so close at hand they look like they're projected on a giant screen through the large windows.

For breakfast, lunch and dinner, the chic Chicagoan Lobby Bar will undoubtedly become your new hangout.

Hotel Chicago Downtown
333 N. Dearborn St.
Chicago, IL 60654

+1 312 245 0333

www.thehotelchicago.com

Rooms: from 189 USD

content.title: Everest, the culinary peak

introduction.small: For more than 30 years, French chef Jean Joho has showcased the cuisine of his country through the surprising fresh reinventions of his fondest childhood dishes.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Everest, the culinary peak

paragraphs.text:
A feast in every sense and for all the senses, starting with the taste buds, subtly awakened by chef Jean Joho, a chef at the summit of his art. Highlights include the Maine lobster roasted in Gewürztraminer wine. The chef's Alsatian origins can be discerned elsewhere, including the restaurant's extensive list of 1,600 wines.

Perched high up on the 40th floor of the Chicago Board of Trade, the views are astounding. The quiet atmosphere of understated elegances is a welcome change from the hubbub of the city's eateries below.

Everest
440 S LaSalle Street, 40th floor
Chicago, IL 60605

+1 312 663 8920

www.everestrestaurant.com

Menu: around 100 USD

content.title: 360 Chicago, a breathtaking view of the Windy City

introduction.small: The vertigo-inducing Tilt in the 360 Chicago tower brings you face-to-face with the city – 310 meters above the ground!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: 360 Chicago, a breathtaking view of the Windy City

paragraphs.text:
Completed in 1969, the John Hancock Center, now nicknamed ‘360 Chicago', rises to 310 meters above the Magnificent Mile. The views from top of the skyline, Lake Michigan, and its beaches, are unbelievable. On clear days, you can see as far as the three bordering States. The 360° view, however, is not the only attraction.

Most thrill seeking tourists come primarily for Tilt: a dive into the void that allows you to gaze out at the city from a dizzying new perspective, thanks to a tilting system of bay windows. A unique experience and very secure, but if you are afraid of heights, beware!

360 Chicago
875 North Michigan Avenue
Chicago, IL 60611

+1 312 654 5019

www.360chicago.com

content.title: The Chicago Theatre, temple of American cinema

introduction.small: Called the “Wonder Theatre of the World”, the Chicago Theatre was the first major movie theatre in the US, and served as a prototype for all others.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Chicago Theatre, temple of American cinema

paragraphs.text:
The grandeur of the Chicago Theatre often leaves visitors speechless. Restored in 1930s style, it reopened on September 10, 1986 with a live Frank Sinatra concert.

A true palace, the Chicago Theatre was for many years the residence of the Balaban & Katz Theatre corporation. Until 1945, it was one of the world's most prestigious cinemas. Listed by the National Register of Historic Places and the Chicago Landmark, it is today one of the city's most popular music venues, for everything from pop concerts to musicals. Built in a French baroque style, the exterior building façade features a stylised, sculpted replica of the Arc de Triomphe, just above the theatre's eye-popping name in neon.

Chicago Theatre
175 N State St
Chicago, IL 60601

+1 312 462 6300

www.thechicagotheatre.com

content.title: The Art Institute of Chicago

introduction.small: Located in the heart of Grant Park, the museum houses one of the world's finest collections of Impressionist and modern art.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Art Institute of Chicago

paragraphs.text:
Built in 1893, the Art Institute of Chicago's collection of Impressionist and Post-Impressionist art is second only to the Musée d'Orsay in Paris.

Designed by architect Renzo Piano, the ‘Modern Wing' contains the third largest collection of modern art in the world, after those of the Centre Pompidou in Paris and the MoMA in New York.

The Architecture and Design department includes more than 250,000 architectural models, drawings and fragments, dating from 1870 to the present, and including works by starchitect names like David Adler, Ludwig Mies van der Rohe and Frank Lloyd Wright.

The Art Institute of Chicago
111 South Michigan Avenue
Chicago, IL 60603

+1 312 443 3600

www.artic.edu

content.title: Millennium Park, an open-air art gallery

introduction.small: This urban garden of the new millennium presents extraordinary contemporary works, making this “green gem” a favourite of Chicagoans.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Millennium Park, an open-air art gallery

paragraphs.text:
Located in the Loop, this park of 99,000 m2, which stretches along Lake Michigan, was the city's largest project for the Universal Exhibition of 1893. At the edges of the shaded paths arise bold contemporary installations, such as the Cloud Gate by Anish Kapoor, a gigantic polished metal ball reflecting the Chicago skyline.

Originally designed as a green space covering an underground car park, the project soon included works by other contemporary architects and artists, such as Frank Gehry's Jay Pritzker Pavilion and BP Bridge, Renzo Piano's South Exelon Pavilion, and Jaume Plensa's Crown Fountain.

Millenium Park
201 E Randolph St
Chicago IL 60602

+1 312 742 1168

www.milleniumpark.org

content.title: Small Cheval, "slow food" gallops into Chicago

introduction.small: Little brother of the nationally recognised restaurant Au Cheval, this hip address in a modern setting is beloved by American diner fans.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Small Cheval, "slow food" gallops into Chicago

paragraphs.text:
Hamburgers, cheeseburgers, bacon burgers, French fries: it only takes a few seconds to read the entire menu at this new restaurant, which has quickly become one of the most frequented addresses in Chicago.

Here, the focus is as much on the authenticity of the raw materials wood and stone used in the décor, as on the freshness of raw materials used in the food. The craft beer list is huge. Far from a fast food joint, Small Cheval is a peaceful haven in the heart of the city.

In nice weather, the hipster patrons relax on the patio, enjoying the finest burgers in the city.

Small Cheval
1732 N. Milwaukee
Chicago, IL 60647

www.smallcheval.com

Menu: around 15 USD

content.title: Cherry Circle Room, intimate ambience with Midwest cuisine

introduction.small: Intimate and authentic, the Cherry Room Circle takes its design cues from Chicago's, Prohibition period ‘speakeasy' bars.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cherry Circle Room, intimate ambience with Midwest cuisine

paragraphs.text:
This is the perfect place to dine after an aperitif at Cindy's, the bar with stunning views on the roof of the same building on Millennium Park.

The canteen of the Chicago Athletic Association, a group of historic buildings mostly converted into hotels, has just been completely renovated in a spirit just as refined and hushed as the original, with upholstered leather chairs and elaborately carved woodwork, but with a more modern twist.

In the kitchen, the young chief Peter Coenen takes his inspiration from a collection of menus, some dating as far back as 1890, to redefine with finesse the rustic mainstays of Chicago's regional cuisine.

Cherry Circle Room
12 S. Michigan Ave.
Chicago, IL 60603

+1 312 792 3515

www.cherrycircleroom.com

Menus: around 40 USD

content.title: The Halal Guys, colourful and copious Mediterranean cuisine

introduction.small: The takeaway queue stretches onto the street at this fashionable eatery, which success equals its NYC counterpart.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Halal Guys, colourful and copious Mediterranean cuisine

paragraphs.text:
They only just landed in Chicago and already they're the talk of the town. Run by New Yorkers who have become icons of Mediterranean cuisine since opening a Middle-Eastern spiced hot dogs stand in 1990, the Halal Guys are now stirring things up on Division Street, which has not experienced such excitement since the filming of About Last Night.

The generous takes on Mediterranean ‘street food' include creamy hummus, deliciously crunchy falafels, with a secret white sauce to die for. The authentic and lively atmosphere makes this one of the city's hottest spots.

The Halal Guys
49 West Division Street
Chicago, IL 60610

+1 312 877 5575

www.thehalalguys.com

Menu: around 25 USD

content.title: Soho House, refined West Loop cocoon

introduction.small: In a “shaker” decor very much in touch with its time, this small 4-star hotel with 40 rooms is a cosy enclave in the heart of the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Soho House, refined West Loop cocoon

paragraphs.text:
The West Loop Chicago Hotel Soho House opened recently in an old tannery. Clues to the industrial origins of this historic building are still evident, starting with the cistern that was originally on the roof.

Meticulously removed piece by piece, it now adorns a mural in the lobby. Its a stunning work of art, but the main reason for moving it was to make room for a 60-foot rooftop swimming pool with unobstructed views of the Chicago skyline. Less flashy but equally valuable in a city of especially cold winters, is the fully equipped spa and gym, with leather workout stations and Chesterfield sofas. The Music Room sets the correct tone, and the movie theatre, tucked away in a hidden room behind the library, is a cinephile's delight.

Soho House
113-125 North Green Street
Chicago IL 60607

+1 312 521 8000

www.sohohousechicago.com

Rooms: from 300 USD

content.title: Take the “L train” for a memorable aerial crossing of the city

introduction.small: Voted by readers of the Chicago Tribune in 2005 as one of the “seven wonders” of the city, the Chicago rapid transit system is inseparable from its landscape.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Take the “L train” for a memorable aerial crossing of the city

paragraphs.text:
Do not ask a Chicagoan where the nearest subway station is, but rather ask them where the ‘L' is. Short for ‘elevated', even though most of it is underground, lovers of the city only have eyes for the raised ‘loop' of the city's rapid transit system, which give its name to the district. Often threatened, it has always been saved at the last minute by popular demand, as Chicagoans have strong attachment to this symbol, which, though ageing, is inseparable from the city's identity.

In the tradition of the large public exhibitions that helped make the reputation of Chicago, 50 works of art - sculptures, paintings and installations - are on view in more than 40 stations.

content.title: Old Chicago Water Tower District, the heart of architectural history

introduction.small: Along the Magnificent Mile, Old Chicago Water Tower District is home to the most beautiful historic buildings in the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Old Chicago Water Tower District, the heart of architectural history

paragraphs.text:
On either side of Michigan Avenue, between East Chicago Street and East Pearson Street, Old Chicago Water Tower District tells the history of the city through its architecture, focused around the Chicago Water Tower. Built in 1869, this small Neo-gothic water tower is a symbol of Chicago, regarded by readers of the Chicago Tribune as one of city's ‘seven wonders '.

An art gallery inside holds free exhibitions of contemporary photography. The building, which, like the Pumping Station and Fire Station No. 98 just opposite, withstood the Great Fire of 1871. It has thus been a privileged witness of Chicago's incredible industrial growth since the late 19th century.

Chicago Water Tower
806 North Michigan Avenue
Chicago, IL 60611

+1 312 742 0808

www.cityofchicago.org

content.title: The Peninsula Chicago, luxury in the heart of the city

introduction.small: Ideally located on fashionable Michigan Avenue, the Peninsula Chicago is destined for sophisticated travellers accustomed to the luxury and excellent service of the Asian chain.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Peninsula Chicago, luxury in the heart of the city

paragraphs.text:
After months of work, the somewhat outdated decor of the 339 rooms is now decidedly designer contemporary, with lots of black and white tones and ebony, bold graphic patterns, and walls decorated with chrysanthemums, the official flower of Chicago.

Controlled entirely by touch pads, the rooms are now a virtual playing field for business travellers and tech buffs. With the ‘Tailor-made VIP' program, you can take an exclusive tour of ‘Old Town' or the Chicago Art Institute, or catch a Broadway show. Or just stay cocooned in your sumptuous room, only emerging for High Tea in the huge Art Deco lobby.

At dusk, aperitifs can be sipped in the subdued atmosphere of the bar, or overlooking the glittering skyline on the Shanghai Terrace, one of the best Chinese restaurants in the city.

The Peninsula Chicago
108 E Superior St
Chicago, IL 60611

+1 312 337 2888

www.chicago.peninsula.com

Rooms: from 399 USD

content.title: Willis Tower, record-breaking skyscraper

introduction.small: Built in 1973 by architect Bruce Graham and first known as the “Sears Tower”, the Willis Tower is one of the most iconic skyscrapers in Chicago.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Willis Tower, record-breaking skyscraper

paragraphs.text:
At 442 meters high and with 108 floors, the Willis Tower lorded over the world's skyscrapers for 25 years before being dethroned by the Petronas Twin Towers in Kuala Lumpur.

It remained the highest in the US before being recently surpassed by One World Trade Center in New York. Despite the fact that the supersonic elevators will bring you to the top in seconds, be sure to stop at the Skydeck on the 103rd floor, for one of the best views of Chicago. You can also enjoy the stunning view from The Ledge, four glass cubes that project out of the tower, giving one the illusion of floating in space.

Willis Tower
223 South Wacker Drive
Chicago, IL 60606

+1 312 875 0066

www.willistower.com

content.title: Alinea, modern Michelin-starred cuisine

introduction.small: Grant Achatz, nicknamed “The Modernist”, offers innovative cuisine acclaimed worldwide, for an address that was elected “Best Restaurant” in the United States three times already.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Alinea, modern Michelin-starred cuisine

paragraphs.text:
Alinea is not a restaurant. At least, not in the conventional sense. Eating there is pure theatre. Since its opening in 2005, it has become a Chicago landmark. With only one seasonal menu of 18 to 22 dishes, the dining experience is not only bold and delicious, it is also moving and provocative.

Everything about this three Michelin starred restaurant is astounding, from the first amuse-bouche to the dazzling finale: a floating green apple helium balloon.

Alinea
1723 North Halsted
Chicago, IL 60614

+1 312 867 0110

www.alinearestaurant.com

Menu: around 300 USD

content.title: Magnificent Mile: a shopping and eating nirvana

introduction.small: Located in the city centre on Michigan Avenue, the Magnificent Mile is full of trendy restaurants, bars, and luxury boutiques.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Magnificent Mile: a shopping and eating nirvana

paragraphs.text:
Chicago's version of Fifth Avenue stretches from the Michigan Bridge on the north bank of the river to Oak Street. Dubbed ‘Mag Mile' by Chicagoans, it has giant shopping centres 900 North Michigan Shops, Water Tower Place with its souvenir shops and a Macy's.

There are countless luxury stores, including Chanel, Burberry, Louis Vuitton and Cartier. It's also a destination for gourmets, most notably for the Cape Cod Room in the Drake Hotel, famous for its oyster bar and fine fish cuisine, and the Italian restaurant Spiaggia, which has a Michelin star.

Magnificent Mile
Michigan Avenue District
Chicago

+1 312 409 5560

www.themagnificentmile.com

content.title: Sea, sun and fun: the beaches of Lake Michigan

introduction.small: Nicknamed “The Third Coast” of the United States, Lake Michigan's long shoreline is broken into 33 dream beaches.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sea, sun and fun: the beaches of Lake Michigan

paragraphs.text:
Soft white sand and 27° C water: Chicago beaches are a summertime must. Equipped with umbrellas and chairs, they are generally named after the streets perpendicular to the shore.

The largest city park, Lincoln Park, has the most famous beaches, including Montrose Beach, the city's longest, North Avenue Beach, the oldest and also one of the most popular, and Oak Street Beach, which has the largest authorised swimming area.

Families throng to Thorndale Beach and Humboldt Park Beach, where the shallow waters make for perfect wading pools. The best strategy is to rent a small motorboat and go for an off-coast swim, far away from the crowds.

+1 312 742 3224

www.cpdbeaches.com

content.title: Frank Lloyd Wright and the "Prairie" style

introduction.small: The shadow of Frank Lloyd Wright, one of the founders of modern architecture, hovers over Chicago. In Oak Park, in the inner suburbs, his “Prairie” style comes into its own.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Frank Lloyd Wright and the "Prairie" style

paragraphs.text:
Far from the urban bustle, the residential area of ​​Oak Park is an architectural marvel, and much more peaceful. Its history is linked forever to architect Frank Lloyd Wright, inventor of “Prairie”, a pioneering style of modernist architecture from the second half of the 20th century.

The house that Wright built here for his family, with its long prairie-like horizontal silhouette, low rooftops extending beyond the walls, and long stretches of windows, terraced and often decorated with stained glass, is a true jewel.

The Chicago Architecture Foundation offers tours, both inside and outside the building, and in the surrounding neighbourhood.

Frank Lloyd Wright Home and Studio
951 Chicago Avenue
Oak Park, IL 60302

+1 312 994 4000

www.architecture.org

content.title: CLIMATE AND WEATHER IN Chicago
content.introduction: Chicago has a humid continental climate. Winters are severe and temperatures often stay well below freezing for long periods between November and March. Blizzards are frequent and snowstorms can occasionally shut down public transport. Summers are hot, with the city regularly experiencing heat waves, sometimes followed by a further period of very warm weather, known as Indian summer, in the early autumn.

content.title: Currency and Exchange Rates
content.description: The currency used in the United States of America is the Dollar (USD).
content.validity: The above exchange rate is given for information because is variable.

airports.title: Chicago O'Hare International Airport
airports.description:
O'Hare International Airport is located about 29 kilometres (18 miles) north-west of Chicago's central business district, known as the Loop.
  • Four terminals:
    • Terminal 1
    • Terminal 2
    • Terminal 3
    • Terminal 5 (Air France)

Getting from the airport to Chicago and back:
  • By car
    • Accessible via I-90 and I-190.
    • There are short-term parking facilities at Terminals 1, 2, 3 and 5 (USD 2 for 1 hour or less, USD 60 for 24 hours) and long-term parking lots with a free shuttle service to the terminals (between USD 10 and USD 17 per day).
    • Several car rental companies have counters at the service centre on the airport property and all of them operate free, 24-hour shuttle buses picking up customers outside the baggage claim areas at each terminal.
  • By shuttle bus
    Go Airport Express buses connect the airport to various city and suburban locations. Fares start at USD 16 each way (50 minutes to the Loop, with departures every 10 to 15 minutes).
  • By rail
    The Chicago Transit Authority (CTA) operates the city's famous "L" trains, with the Blue Line running directly from the airport to the Loop. The O'Hare station is located on the lower level of the parking garage and trains run 24 hours a day and 7 days a week. The fare is USD 5 each way.
  • By Taxi
    There are taxi stands outside baggage claim at each terminal. The trip to the Loop will take about 40 minutes and the average fare is about USD 40.
  • Services: shops, bars and restaurants, Internet access (Wi-Fi) available in the airport
  • Telephone:+1 800 832 6352
  • Website:www.flychicago.com/ohare/

transportation.title: GETTING AROUND Chicago
transportation.description: For years, Chicago has shown that the dark periods having tarnished its international reputation are truly a thing of the past! Today, Chicago is a very enjoyable place to visit and one that is particularly well served by its public transport system. Known as a city of distinctive neighbourhoods, Chicago is perhaps best seen on foot or by bicycle.

touristInformation.title: Visitor information
touristInformation.description: Upon your arrival in Chicago, you can get in touch with local tourism professionals for further information and to help organize your stay.

information.title: Chicago Visitor Information Centers
information.description:
These two centres, operated by Choose Chicago, the city's official destination marketing organization, offer practical information and many useful recommendations (accommodation, restaurants, public transport, festivals, cultural events, etc.).

Chicago Cultural Center

  • Address: 77, East Randolph Street - The Loop
  • Telephone: +1 312 744 6630
  • Website: www.cityofchicago.org/city/en/depts/dca/supp_info/chicago_culturalcenter.html

Macy's on State Street

  • Address: 111 N. State Street, Lower Level
  • Telephone: +1 312 781 1000
  • Website: www.visitmacysusa.com

The website maintained by Choose Chicago (http://www.choosechicago.com), also provides a wealth of information for visitors to Chicago.

information.title: Further information available online for visitors to the United States
information.description: Visit the USA, a public-private marketing entity, works closely with the travel industry to promote tourism in communities around the country. Its website offers excellent information on all US travel destinations, including Chicago: https://www.visittheusa.co.uk/destination/chicago

medical.title: Medical information
medical.description: See your doctor before you travel. It is also recommended to take out insurance covering medical expenses and repatriation before your trip. Chicago counts several hospitals and medical institutions, as well as quality medical practitioners and health specialists.

information.title: Vaccinations
information.description:
There are no vaccination requirements for visitors to the United States.

For more information, contact Air France's international vaccination centre:

  • Address: 38, quai de Jemmapes, 75010 Paris
  • Website: https://www.vaccinations-airfrance.fr/
  • Telephone: +33 (0)1 43 17 22 00
  • To make a vaccination appointment:
    • online (click here)
    • call the centre at +33 (0)1 43 17 22 00

information.title: Food safety
information.description: There are no food safety risks in Chicago.

information.title: Water
information.description: Tap water is safe to drink in Chicago.

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Chicago
localCalendar.description:
There are a number of festivals, holidays and other events celebrated in Chicago each year.
The main ones are listed below.

events.title: Third Monday in January : Martin Luther King Day (national holiday)
events.description: A federal holiday in the United States, celebrating the life and achievements of Martin Luther King, Jr. In recent years, it has increasingly been seen as a day of service, when Americans are encouraged to volunteer to help others less fortunate than themselves. Many events inspired by Dr. King's legacy are held each year in Chicago: musical concerts, other performances, exhibitions, debates.

events.title: January - February : Chinese New Year (celebrated nationwide in major cities)
events.description: Festivities are held each year to ring in the Chinese New Year in Chicago's Chinatown, one of the largest such neighbourhoods in the world, including a big parade along Wentworth Ave., from Cermak Rd. to 24th St.), and includes marching bands, floats, dragon and lion dance performers, and a 100-foot paper dragon. There are also martial arts demonstrations.

events.title: June - September: Ravinia Festival (local event)
events.description: The oldest outdoor music festival in the United States and a premier cultural destination for Chicagoans, Ravinia welcomes world-class musicians each summer to several venues in the northern Chicago suburb of Highland Park. Enjoying often elaborate picnic dinners under the stars, concertgoers can choose from a vast array of classical, pop, folk, jazz, dance and family-oriented programmes.

events.title: July 4 : Independence Day (national holiday)
events.description: A federal holiday in the United States commemorating the adoption of the Declaration of Independence on July 4, 1776, by which the 13 American colonies officially severed their political ties with Great Britain. Celebrated with parades, barbecues, picnics and fireworks.

events.title: First Monday in September: Labour Day (national holiday)
Labour Day weekend : Chicago Jazz Festival (local event)
events.description: Without a doubt, one of the world's leading jazz festivals. Over this three-day period, more than fifty concerts are presented in Grant Park. Admission is free!

events.title: First Monday in September : Labour Day (national holiday)
Second Monday in October : Columbus Day (national holiday)
events.description: Commemorates the landing of Christopher Columbus in the New World (October 12, 1492). Many cultural events are organized to mark this anniversary each year, including performances, exhibitions and parades.

events.title: October 31 : Halloween (celebrated nationwide)
events.description: Halloween is celebrated each year by Americans of all ages. In the late afternoon and early evening hours, children don costumes and go door-to-door in their neighbourhoods to ask for treats, typically candy. Adults often attend costume parties in the evening.

events.title: Fourth Thursday in November : Thanksgiving (national holiday)
events.description: Originally a Christian religious observance, for many years Thanksgiving has been a secular holiday in the United States, celebrated by Americans of all faiths. Families come together to prepare and enjoy a large feast at home. The meal typically includes roast turkey with stuffing, mashed potatoes, cranberry sauce as well as various side dishes and ends with an assortment of pies (pumpkin, pecan, apple).

administrativeProcedures.title: Entry requirements for the United States
administrativeProcedures.description:
The Visa Waiver Program (VWP) allows French citizens to travel to the United States without a visa for stays of 90 days or less, whether for tourism or business. Two requirements must be met:

  • Your passport must meet the criteria for VWP travel (it must be machine-readable, with an integrated chip containing information from the passport data page). For further information, visit the Visa Waiver Program page on the Website of the Bureau of Consular Affairs, U.S. Department of State: https://travel.state.gov/content/visas/en/visit/visa-waiver-program.html
  • You must have a valid Electronic System for Travel Authorization (ESTA) prior to travel. For further information, visit the ESTA page on the U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) Website: http://www.cbp.gov/travel/international-visitors/esta
    https://esta.cbp.dhs.gov/esta

Travellers not eligible for the VWP, or who have not been able to obtain an ESTA, must apply for a visa.

To enjoy peace of mind during your stay in Chicago and the United States, follow the travel advice of the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs:

https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/country-files/united-states/#

goodToKnow.title: Good to know

administration.title: Government offices
administration.openingHours: Usually open Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. and 2:30 p.m. to 5 p.m.

banks.title: Banks
banks.openingHours: Usually open Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m. and Saturday from 9 a.m. to noon

goodToKnow.daylightSavingTime:
Start of daylight saving time: second Sunday in March
End of daylight saving time: first Sunday in November
goodToKnow.tips:
Tipping
In Chicago as in the rest of the United States, a service charge is not included in the bill and tips form a major portion of income for waiting staff. Prices on restaurant menus are indicated before taxes and tips. You are therefore expected to leave a tip (generally between 15 and 20% of the bill). Tipping less than 15% (or leaving no tip at all) means that you are very dissatisfied with the service
